data.text: Is It Normal for Goretex Rain Gear to be Damp?

I just recently bought some goretex rain gear.... REI brand and I took it out and both pieces the jacket and pants was wet on the inside form the rain precipitating though it, like it was damp. Is that normal? I only went out for a 20 minute ride. As that normal? Or does it have to two that REI only uses two layers?
Sweat?

data.text: No

data.text: I don't think you have to be "sticky". Maybe not even noticeably wet. Try more gear in the same situation and see what results you get. The fact that you already had two pieces of gear "fail" indicates it could be something other than gear failure. So again I'd try more gear before I was too sure of anything. I don't think I've ever had a waterproof item that didn't work.
data.author: David Baker-Yuill

data.text: Bottom line is I don't think there is a solution, other than having pit zips and making sure your wearing synthetic insulation underneath. It just happens, especially if your fully zipped up.

data.text: Sounds like sweat man… You sweat without realizing it.
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: It is condensation from the warm moist air around your body hitting the cool jacket. Your physical activity makes more heat and moisture than your breathable jacket can handle. The test would be to go out in the rain but with little physical activity. If the inside still gets wet, than its the jacket. You might have to opt for the more expensive brands. I have a marmot goretex that works quite well, although I’ve not eorn it on a tour.

data.text: I don’t know. I gave up on raingear except in really heavy downpours because you end up just as wet but wearing clunky raingear. I’ve had the best results with premium high breathability like Goretex Pac-lite or PRO.

data.text: Only way to stay dry when exercising is have a way for body moisture to escape For rain jackets it is under arm zipper vents Pants h’mmmm
data.author: Charles Nighbor

data.text: My experience with gore tex is that if you are working hard on the bike and it's raining, you get wet inside no matter what. The gore tex cannot remove moisture any faster than the rate of evaporation from its outer surface, and in heavy rain that is essentially zero. You sweat and it condenses onto the inside of the fabric. Also unless you have tailwind some of the rain will be getting in around your face. Having said that, except in very hot weather I don't sweat from my legs and my legs stay dry. As far as I can tell the marketing claims by these jacket manufacturers are a bit of a con.
data.author: Hugh Warrington

data.text: Nothing has ever kept me dry with vigorous exercise in the rain. I can't tell whether it's leaking through or condensing inside, but I'm wet.
data.author: David Welch

data.text: K you for your advice!
data.author: Patrick Rowland

data.text: A wise person once told me it's either raining on the outside or it's raining on the inside. My goretex is mostly for wind and warmth and standing around. YMMV
data.author: Chuck Perry

data.text: It's normal from my experiences with goretex. I have quite a warm body temp and I suspect the moisture I create combines with external moisture and encourages goretex to wick through to the inside. I've owned numerous goretex products and while they work in low humidity rain showers they have all failed during physical activity in rainy conditions.
data.author: Johnny Ryall

data.text: It is normal to sweat and 'wet-out' gear from the inside. Pit zips, and front pockets that can also act as vents, help. If you wear a base layer and middle layer that both wick away moisture, that will keep your body dry, and thus warmer. People often think the purpose of a base layer is to keep you warm. It is probably better to think of it as keeping you dry, so that you don't chill from wet skin. Wool is a good base layer and it will retain heat, even when damp.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: Addendum. Sweat and condensation together. Especially condensation in cold weather.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: You can try an experiment and wear the same gear when it’s not raining. Almost certainly you’ll find the waterproofs are wet from condensed water vapour on the inside. Our bodies constantly produce some vapour even at rest. But goretex does work, the same experiment wearing a bin liner will prove that.
data.author: John Knapp

data.text: The opposite experiment is to pour water over the jacket when you’re not wearing it. I’d expect it to be ‘waterproof’.
data.author: John Knapp

data.text: You can test the waterproofness quite easily by suspending a portion of the material over a bowl in a way that forms a hollow and filling it with water, see how much gets through, I doubt it's any. Condensation is worse when it's raining, the rain is likely t make the outer surface cooler which increases the differential which is the cause. A surface that beads the water so it runs off is of more use than the breathability. And of course reducing that differential, if you're already warm, don't put the jacket over a jersey, when it rains I replace one with the other.
data.author: Paul Hilditch

data.text: As many have written: your own transpiration Therefore, i think it is good to: -try to find clothes with extra ventilation (for me mandatory: both way zipper on the front) -wear as less as possible clothes below the rain coat. It will anyway be soaked. And don’t forget: your body is warm, the transpiration is humid air. Mostly, the outside air is cold, and saturated: it won’t easily take up more humidity. And we all remember what’s happening when warm humid air meets a cold place: water is condensing, in that particular case in your rain gear. 🤓 (I love the mountain equipment odyssey)
data.author: Georges Froidevaux

data.text: Rain gear is about staying WARM, not DRY. Use it to manage your temperature.
data.author: John Almond

data.text: Pretty much.
data.author: Michael Viglianco

data.text: You are a source of humidity and moisture within your gear. Gore-tex is meant to move moisture from a high humidity environment to a lower. If it is actively raining and high humidity outside, these semi-permeable fabrics will not work as totally as you may want. Every physical barrier reaches a compromise in it's level of performance. John Almond is right. Stay WARM and not Dry. Hypothermia is very real, if you stop in cold wind. Perhaps a wool sweater might be better if it is not pouring rain.
data.author: Jonathan Harman

data.text: Wear Merino or anything that doesn't soak water under the gortex.... Body perspiration and natural respiration is natural...... The other consideration is to avoid perspiring so much to overwhelm the ability of Gortex to let the moisture out.... It's always a balance in riding, it's very very very rare that I'm exactly comfortable not too hot or too cold.... Not to wet or too dry.... Like doing literally anything, it's never exactly perfect for very long if ever.
